<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 98, 771, 114]]<|/det|>
UNIVERSITY OF CAMBRIDGE INTERNATIONAL EXAMINATIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 114, 475, 129]]<|/det|>
General Certificate of Education

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 129, 613, 145]]<|/det|>
Advanced Subsidiary Level and Advanced Level

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 195, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
**MATHEMATICS**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 195, 908, 208]]<|/det|>
9709/42

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 217, 304, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics 1 (M1)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 217, 908, 231]]<|/det|>
May/June 2013

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 240, 907, 253]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 260, 455, 274]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 273, 388, 287]]<|/det|>
Graph Paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 287, 458, 301]]<|/det|>
List of Formulae (MF9)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 322, 390, 336]]<|/det|>
# READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 325, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 497, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 601, 431]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 908, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 510, 590, 525]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 606, 541]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 558, 606, 572]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 573, 756, 588]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 590, 440, 604]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 908, 635]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 865, 728, 879]]<|/det|>
This document consists of 3 printed pages and 1 blank page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A string is attached to a block of weight \(30 \mathrm{~N}\), which is in contact with a rough horizontal plane. When the string is horizontal and the tension in it is \(24 \mathrm{~N}\), the block is in limiting equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 154, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 665, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of friction between the block and the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
The block is now in motion and the string is at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) upwards from the plane. The tension in the string is \(25 \mathrm{~N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 197, 151, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 432, 215]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 199, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 243, 96, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
A and \(B\) are two points 50 metres apart on a straight path inclined at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal, where \(\sin \theta = 0.05\), with \(A\) above the level of \(B\). A block of mass \(16 \mathrm{~kg}\) is pulled down the path from \(A\) to \(B\). The block starts from rest at \(A\) and reaches \(B\) with a speed of \(10 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\). The work done by the pulling force acting on the block is \(1150 \mathrm{~J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 322, 153, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 322, 576, 340]]<|/det|>
Find the work done against the resistance to motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 323, 920, 341]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 352, 920, 387]]<|/det|>
The block is now pulled up the path from \(B\) to \(A\). The work done by the pulling force and the work done against the resistance to motion are the same as in the case of the downward motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 400, 153, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 400, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
Show that the speed of the block when it reaches \(A\) is the same as its speed when it started at \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 415, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 462, 96, 480]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 470, 727, 579]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 597, 920, 679]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(2.1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to one end of each of two light inextensible strings. The other ends of the strings are attached to points \(A\) and \(B\) which are at the same horizontal level. \(P\) hangs in equilibrium at a point \(40 \mathrm{~cm}\) below the level of \(A\) and \(B\), and the strings \(PA\) and \(PB\) have lengths \(50 \mathrm{~cm}\) and \(104 \mathrm{~cm}\) respectively (see diagram). Show that the tension in the string \(PA\) is \(20 \mathrm{~N}\), and find the tension in the string \(PB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 662, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 707, 92, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 707, 920, 759]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is released from rest at the top of a smooth plane which is inclined at an angle \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, where \(\sin \alpha = \frac{16}{65}\). The distance travelled by \(P\) from the top to the bottom is \(S\) metres, and the speed of \(P\) at the bottom is \(8 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 774, 153, 791]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 774, 809, 791]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(S\) and hence find the speed of \(P\) when it has travelled \(\frac{1}{2} S\) metres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 775, 920, 793]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 804, 774, 822]]<|/det|>
The time taken by \(P\) to travel from the top to the bottom of the plane is \(T\) seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 836, 153, 854]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 836, 853, 854]]<|/det|>
Find the distance travelled by \(P\) at the instant when it has been moving for \(\frac{1}{2} T\) seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 836, 920, 855]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1000\mathrm{kg}\) is travelling on a straight horizontal road. The power of its engine is constant and equal to \(P\mathrm{kW}\). The resistance to motion of the car is \(600\mathrm{N}\). At an instant when the car's speed is \(25\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\), its acceleration is \(0.2\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 2}\). Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 131, 148, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 131, 279, 149]]<|/det|>
the value of \(P\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 155, 153, 174]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 155, 510, 174]]<|/det|>
the steady speed at which the car can travel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 156, 920, 174]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 202, 96, 220]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 201, 920, 269]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line. It starts from rest at a point \(O\) and moves towards a point \(A\) on the line. During the first 8 seconds \(P\)'s speed increases to \(8\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) with constant acceleration. During the next 12 seconds \(P\)'s speed decreases to \(2\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) with constant deceleration. \(P\) then moves with constant acceleration for 6 seconds, reaching \(A\) with speed \(6.5\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 282, 151, 300]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 281, 531, 300]]<|/det|>
Sketch the velocity-time graph for \(P\)'s motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 282, 920, 300]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 312, 740, 330]]<|/det|>
The displacement of \(P\) from \(O\), at time \(t\) seconds after \(P\) leaves \(O\), is \(s\) metres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 344, 151, 362]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 344, 900, 362]]<|/det|>
Shade the region of the velocity-time graph representing \(s\) for a value of \(t\) where \(20 \leqslant t \leqslant 26\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 359, 920, 377]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 153, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 390, 374, 408]]<|/det|>
Show that, for \(20 \leqslant t \leqslant 26\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 415, 598, 435]]<|/det|>
\[s = 0.375t^{2} - 13t + 202.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 415, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 470, 96, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 477, 757, 567]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 586, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
Particles \(A\) of mass \(0.26\mathrm{kg}\) and \(B\) of mass \(0.52\mathrm{kg}\) are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a small smooth pulley \(P\) which is fixed at the top of a smooth plane. The plane is inclined at an angle \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, where \(\sin \alpha = \frac{16}{65}\) and \(\cos \alpha = \frac{63}{65}\). \(A\) is held at rest at a point 2.5 metres from \(P\), with the part \(AP\) of the string parallel to a line of greatest slope of the plane. \(B\) hangs freely below \(P\) at a point \(0.6\mathrm{m}\) above the floor (see diagram). \(A\) is released and the particles start to move. Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 691, 151, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 691, 779, 710]]<|/det|>
the magnitude of the acceleration of the particles and the tension in the string,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 691, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 715, 153, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 715, 920, 749]]<|/det|>
the speed with which \(B\) reaches the floor and the distance of \(A\) from \(P\) when \(A\) comes to instantaneous rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 732, 920, 750]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
